trial_identification.studytitle: The effectiveness of Brief-Alcohol, Smoking, Substance Involvement Screening Test (Brief-ASSIST) Linked Brief Intervention (BI) for substance abuse among schizophrenic patients
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effectiveness of a Brief-ASSIST Linked Brief Intervention (BI) for the treatment of substance abuse among schizophrenic patients

interventions.interventions:
Arm 1: Brief Intervention = 1 session (1 hour/session) of motivational interview + Goal setting + Relapse prevention (The intervention is one-on-one therapy with a psychiatric nurse). Arm 2: Brief Intervention + Family Session = Brief Intervention plus 1 session (30 minutes/session) of family psychoeducation (The intervention is one-on-one therapy with a psychiatric nurse).
More explaination about Brief ASSIST linked Brief Intervention: The brief-ASSIST scores can divide the clients into three categories including low, moderate and high risk categories and the brief-ASSIST has its specific brief intervention for the clients in moderate risk category (no intervention for low risk category and more intensive intervention for high risk category).
interventions.comparator: Standard treatment: The participants will receive all of standard psychiatric care from the hospital such as psychiatric drug and psychoeducation about schizophrenic symptoms and medication side effect. Then, they will be treated with brief advice about the bad effect of such substance and give the general advice to stop using substance such as do more exercise, play the music, and eat good food.

primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, and at 3 and 6 months after intervention commencement

primaryOutcome.outcome: The days of substance use and the amounts of substance use in each day in past three month as assessed using a Timeline Followback (a calendar style evaluation form)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, and at 3 and 6 months after intervention commencement

primaryOutcome.outcome: The process of change and readiness to change substance using behavior as assessed using a Stages of Change Readiness and Treatment Eagerness Scale (SOCRATE)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, and at 3 and 6 months after intervention commencement

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Substance related problems as assessed using an Addiction Severity Index (ASI)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, and at 3 and 6 months after intervention commencement

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Emotional and behavioral symptoms as assessed using a Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, and at 3 and 6 months after intervention commencement

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Functional status as assessed using a Global Assessment of Functioning scale (GAF)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, and at 3 and 6 months after intervention commencement

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Family functional status as assessed using a Global Assessment of Relational Functioning scale (GARF)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, and at 3 and 6 months after intervention commencement

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1.Patients met the ICD-10 criteria of schizophrenia (F20), Acute & transient psychotic disorders (F23) & Unspecified nonorganic psychosis (F29) diagnosed by psychiatrists 2.Those whose score at the moderate-risk Brief-ASSIST level 3.Understand and can speak Thai
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1.Communication difficulties or cognitive impairment 2.Severe behavioral disturbances 3.Comorbid organic disorder and/or mental retardation 4.Drug and alcohol intoxication or severe withdrawal

trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation by using a randomization table created by a computer software

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Study objective: To study the effectiveness of the Brief-Alcohol, Smoking, Substance Involvement Screening Test (Brief-ASSIST) Linked Brief Intervention for substance abuse among schizophrenic patients. Study hypothesis: This early intervention is expected to help decrease disease burden related with schizophrenia and substance use disorder
